body: @piiswrong Thanks for your advice, I've added a link #6754
@piiswrong can we reopen this? We still need access to the original graphic and I was hoping @tqchen can provide it. I think he committed the graphic.

can you try some simple example codes first:

import mxnet as mx
a = mx.nd.ones((2, 3), mx.gpu())
b = a * 2 + 1
b.asnumpy()

does this work?

I mainly use R

 

And yes the code is working.

 

Kim

 

> library(mxnet)

> a = mx.nd.ones(c(2, 3), mx.gpu())

> b = a * 2 + 1

> as.array(b)

     [,1] [,2] [,3]

[1,]    3    3    3

[2,]    3    3    3

>

Is there a reason for having grad.req to "add" rather than "write" as the later seems the proper way to go as in #1715? In the RNN rewrite I use, grad.req is set to "write" and behaves just fine. 

Is the intent to refactor based on the new mx.symbol.RNN?

Actually, I think this commit's approach is better: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/6747/commits/c1fd7889a6700b005989e8d5bef45c626a45ca64

Hi @jermainewang ,

Hugh Perkins has provided [NVIDIA® CUDA™ cuDNN API for Coriander, OpenCL 1.2](https://github.com/hughperkins/coriander-dnn) which ideally should be able to interface with existing Mxnet NVIDIA® CUDA™ cuDNN API.

Could you take a look if it make sense to connect Mxnet with OpenCL through this interface?
I tried this too, but I got the same error

Also: ROCm/HIP support for mxnet is a thing, might be worth moving wholesale that direction to cover CUDA/HIP ootb, and supporting OpenCL via Coriander. Not sure whether Coriander works on HIP code, but if the HIP is compiled via the CUDA path I don't see why not.. might even reduce the API surface for Coriander to cover?

https://github.com/ROCmSoftwarePlatform/mxnet
--

@sbodenstein， @piiswrong 
I use the librispeech for English, and my own corpus for mandarin, which has about 1,400 hours (major in reading data). 

Because issues of MXNet with warp-ctc, so I have no result in MXNet yet. For Keras based coming from Baidu github, which is similar with the MXNet's example.
Architecture: 
1 Conv (1024, 11*1, stride 2, relu) + BN
3 GRU (1024, relu) + BN
1 FC (linear)
https://github.com/baidu-research/ba-dls-deepspeech/blob/master/model.py

For the limitation of GPU, small batch size with 8 or 16 is used during the training. 
All models are optimized by nesterov SGD with the init learning rate 4e-4, with momentum 0.9, gradient norm is clipped by 100.

1. For English, I build the model with English character, which has 29 labels including SPACE
2. For Mandarin, I build the model in two ways, no SPACE label for mandarin modeling.
 1). phone-level modeling with 218 labels;
 2). character-level modeling with 4816 labels 

For three models, the final loss seem to be around 40 and bad CER about 40%+. 

**How can I optimize the RNN architecture? Is there any tip for optimizing LSTM/GRU?**
how to choose a good optimizer?
how to decide a good learning rate? **for example, if SGD is chosen with clip norm=100, and the norm of gradient for all the weights is about 10 to 20, in this case, how can I choose a good learning rate for training?**
how to normalization the feature? with global cmvn? or cmvn per utterance?
......

Many thanks

@chao1224 I have an object ('model_version') that has some network options such as the iteration type (whether to save the (training, validation, testing) metrics at each batch, or epoch):
```python
    def format_metrics(self, model, metrics, val_iter, test_iter = None):
        """
        :param model: mx.Module object
        :param metrics: mx.EvalMetric object
        :param val_iter: mx.io.CSVIter object
        :param test_iter: mx.io.CSVIter object (optional)
        """
        train_value = metrics.get_name_value()
        metrics.reset() #- necessary

        for val_batch in val_iter:
            model.forward(val_batch, is_train = False)
            model.update_metric(metrics, val_batch.label)

        val_iter.reset()  
        valid_value = metrics.get_name_value()
        metrics.reset() #- necessary

        test_types = []
        test_values = []

        if test_iter:
            for test_batch in test_iter:
                model.forward(test_batch, is_train = False)
                model.update_metric(metrics, test_batch.label)
            test_value = metrics.get_name_value()
            metrics.reset() # - necessary
            test_iter.reset()
            test_types, test_values = zip(*test_value)
            test_types = ['test-' + s for s in test_types]

        train_types, train_values = zip(*train_value)
        train_types = ['train-' + s for s in train_types]
        valid_types, valid_values = zip(*valid_value)
        valid_types = ['valid-' + s for s in valid_types]
        return (train_types + valid_types + test_types, train_values + valid_values + test_values)

# iterate through the number of epochs
for epoch in range(model_version.epochs):
     for batch_number, train_batch in enumerate(train_iter):
          model.forward(train_batch, is_train = True)
          model.update_metric(metrics, train_batch.label)
          model.backward()
          model.update()
          if model_version.iteration_type == 'batch':
               self.format_metrics(model, model_version.metrics, val_iter, test_iter)
    
     # option to save metrics at epochs if the iteration type is epoch instead of batch
    if model_version.iteration_type == 'epoch':
          values = self.format_metrics(model, metrics, val_iter, test_iter)
     train_iter.reset() # start the iterator from the first batch before starting a new epoch

I solved this by setting KNOWN_CUDA_ARCHS to 61 in mxnet/Makefile.
and MSHADOW_CFLAGS += -DMSHADOW_USE_PASCAL=1 in mxnet/mshadow/make/mshadow.mk
I also had to use the Makefile build instead of cmake.
Solved in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/6204

@piiswrong Is there a pattern you use to check failure modes? (like assertRaises in unit test).

Im drafting a test:

```
def test_set_params():
    # data iter
    mx.random.seed(11)
    data = mx.nd.array([[0.05, .10]]);
    label = mx.nd.array([[.01, 0.99]]);
    train_data = mx.io.NDArrayIter(data, label, batch_size=1)

    # symbols
    x = mx.symbol.Variable('data')
    x = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(name='fc_0', data=x, num_hidden=2)
    x = mx.symbol.Activation(name="act_0", data=x, act_type='sigmoid')
    x = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(name='fc_1', data=x, num_hidden=2)
    x = mx.symbol.Activation(name="act_1", data=x, act_type='sigmoid')
    x = mx.symbol.LinearRegressionOutput(data=x, name='softmax', grad_scale=2)


    # create module
    mod = mx.mod.Module(x, context=[mx.cpu()]);
    mod.bind(train_data.provide_data, label_shapes=train_data.provide_label,
                    for_training=True)
    arg_params = {'fc_2_weight'  : mx.nd.array([.60, .60])}
    
    # Should raise an error
    mod.set_params(arg_params=arg_params, aux_params={}, allow_missing=True, allow_extra=False)

    # Should not raise an error
    mod.set_params(arg_params=arg_params, aux_params={}, allow_missing=True, allow_extra=True)

    # TODO: Test allow missing (might as well)
    # TODO: Test both 'allow' == False
```
@BiranLi Y do you need label shape?  This op acts like a shortcut in resnet. You can write a simple testing code.

### A list of frontend changes in this PR

Note: rsp is short for row_sparse
- Frontend changes: 
  NDArrayBase
  -> NDArray
  -> SparseNDArray
  -> CSRNDArray / RowSparseNDArray 

- All `NDArray(NDArrayHandle(handle))` is replaced by `_ndarray_cls(NDArrayHandle(handle))` to construct NDArray/CSRNDArray/RowSparseNDArray based on storage type
- Added `to_rsp`, `to_csr` and `to_dense` method for NDArray storage type conversion
- Implemented `zeros`, `load`, `save` for SparseNDArray, functions are moved to ndarray_utils 
- `SparseNDArray` only supports [:] for assignment
- support `__getitem__` with rows for CSRNDArray, but not for RowSparseNDArray
- `__iadd__`, `__imul__`, `__idiv___`, `__isub__` is not supported for SparseNDArray. `__add__`, `__mul__`, etc are inherited from NDArray
- `at`, `reshape`, `broadcast_to`, `T` not supported for SparseNDArray yet
- user is able to retrieve aux (dense) NDArray via `indices`, `values` and `indptr` properties (`indptr` is only available for CSRNArray)
- `Variable` has one more attr called `__storage_type__`
- List of operators implemented (CPU only - many of them shares templated implementation but don't have great performance on GPU):
  `elemwise_add` (row_sparse)
  `cast_storage` (csr<->dense, rsp<->dense, forward only) 
  `dot` (csr dot dense, csr.T dot dense, csr dot row_sparse, csr.T dot row_sparse) 
  `sparse_embedding` (does the same thing as dot, expect weight is auto-allocated)
  `sparse_retain` (see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/5800/files#diff-1b545c728261fd4bf9d82d1340ea7a63R275) 
  `sgd_update` & `sgd_mom_update` (only updating weights with non-zeros rows in gradient, when either weight or gradient is row_sparse)
- `LibSVMIter` reads libsvm format input and output `CSRNDArray`  
- `NDArrayIter` can accept `CSRNDArray` as input 
- kvstore is able to initialize `row_sparse` weight

TODO list
- [ ] kvstore API needs to adopt changes in #6765
- [ ] remove infer_storage_type python interface 
- [ ] Add test for multi-dimensional RowSparse NDArray
- [x] remove shared memory `_slice` for SparseNDArray, always perform slice and assign
- [ ] merge unary & binary operators from Chris's branch
- [ ] bug fix for `NDArrayIter` and `LibSVMIter` (https://github.com/eric-haibin-lin/mxnet/issues/110 https://github.com/eric-haibin-lin/mxnet/issues/98)
- [ ] Plus the ones I mentioned in the previous review
- [ ] refactor ReduceSumCPUExSerial and ReduceSumCPUExparallel
```

@hesseltuinhof Thank you for catching this.

The python Alexnet symbol has been fixed in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/5019

If you installed the prebuilt pkg provided by us, it should include openblas.

You can find how to change the number of threads in openblas from https://github.com/xianyi/OpenBLAS#set-the-number-of-threads-with-environment-variables
I think #6773 will also fix this. @cjolivier01

A similar issue has been reported before ( #1594 ) and it is due to the CUDNN.

Can you try to rebuild the mxnet without cudnn?
Can you try to set a small batch.size? like `array.batch.size = 30` ?

I think the prediction with `mx.gpu()` works on Linux.

Did you compile the pkg by yourself or use the prebuilt pkg provided by us?

I compiled everything by myself using msvc 8 and mingw64 for r build.

Kim
